repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Some LSP backends (`ruby-lsp` in particular here) can return a `nil` response to the `textDocument/diagnostic` method. This is contrary to the LSP spec, but unfortunately it means that neovim doesn't clear previous diagnostics when the `nil` response is received.

This PR changes the handling of the diagnostic response to treat a `nil` response the same as an empty `[]` response.

Fixes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26640

comment_data.body:
Nit but I find the `response` redundant.
```suggestion
        "LSP: client '%s' (id %s) returned nil to textDocument/diagnostic.\nThis is a bug in the LSP backend, and should be fixed within '%s'.",
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -298,15 +298,25 @@ function M.on_diagnostic(_, result, ctx, config)
   local uri = ctx.params.textDocument.uri
   local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
 
-  if result == nil then
-    return
-  end
-
-  if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
-    return
+  local diagnostics = {}
+  if result ~= nil then
+    if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
+      return
+    end
+    diagnostics = result.items
+  else
+    local client_name = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id).name
+    vim.notify_once(
+      string.format(
+        "LSP: client '%s' (id %s) returned nil response to textDocument/diagnostic.\nThis is a bug in the LSP backend, and should be fixed within '%s'.",

comment_data.body:
Question: So this PR doesn't change any behaviors other than making a warning, right? In the description you say "this PR *changes* the handling of the diagnostic response to treat a nil response the same as an empty [] response", but it does not look like the response is like "no diagnostics" (i.e. clear the diagnostics).

When `result` is nil, in both before & after this PR the function handler will return immediately without clearing the diagnostics (`vim.diagnostic.set()`); the behavior is just like "unchanged" (`UnchangedDocumentDiagnosticReport`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -298,15 +298,25 @@ function M.on_diagnostic(_, result, ctx, config)
   local uri = ctx.params.textDocument.uri
   local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
 
-  if result == nil then
-    return
-  end
-
-  if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
-    return
+  local diagnostics = {}
+  if result ~= nil then

comment_data.body: While adding this ad-hoc warning message is fine in this PR, it should be noted that other handlers might throw errors (e.g. `workspace/applyEdit`) or silently ignore the invalid responses (e.g. `textDocument/definition`). (I'm not asking this should be fixed now) As we do further refactoring, this could be better handled in the common "boilerplate error validation and logging" wrapper for the handlers.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -298,15 +298,25 @@ function M.on_diagnostic(_, result, ctx, config)
   local uri = ctx.params.textDocument.uri
   local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
 
-  if result == nil then
-    return
-  end
-
-  if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
-    return
+  local diagnostics = {}
+  if result ~= nil then
+    if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
+      return
+    end
+    diagnostics = result.items
+  else
+    local client_name = vim.lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id).name
+    vim.notify_once(
+      string.format(
+        "LSP: client '%s' (id %s) returned nil to textDocument/diagnostic.\nThis is a bug in the LSP backend, and should be fixed within '%s'.",
+        client_name,
+        client_id,
+        client_name
+      ),
+      vim.log.levels.WARN
+    )

comment_data.body:
This PR does change the behaviour.

When result is nil, `diagnostics` (on line 301) will now be an empty table.

On line 320 we only exit early if there is no buffer attached for the file.

Otherwise we will continue down to the end of this function where on line 346 we call `vim.diagnostic.set` with an empty table, which clears the diagnostics.

I'll add a test for this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -298,15 +298,25 @@ function M.on_diagnostic(_, result, ctx, config)
   local uri = ctx.params.textDocument.uri
   local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
 
-  if result == nil then
-    return
-  end
-
-  if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
-    return
+  local diagnostics = {}
+  if result ~= nil then

comment_data.body:
I see, thanks for detailed explanation. `#diagnostics == 0` **and** `vim.fn.bufexists(fname) == 0`.

Actually I am not convinced that the handler should behave so (i.e. treat `nil` as if it were an empty diagnostic list), when LSP responds an invalid response `nil`. To me, it feels like an over-correction specific to the behavior of the ruby LSP. Would this be a *common* error or mistake across many LSPs? What if it were meant to be like a "unchanged" response by other (buggy) LSP servers? 

As a *workaround*, an user may override the handler to change the semantics of and behaviors on `nil` to "empty diagnostics", in case the LSP server is yet to be fixed and behaves buggy. But I'm not sure this is something the default LSP handler should change for.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -298,15 +298,25 @@ function M.on_diagnostic(_, result, ctx, config)
   local uri = ctx.params.textDocument.uri
   local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(uri)
 
-  if result == nil then
-    return
-  end
-
-  if result.kind == 'unchanged' then
-    return
+  local diagnostics = {}
+  if result ~= nil then

comment_data.body:
That's an excellent point. It's definitely possible that another possible interpretation of `nil` would be "unchanged".

What would it look like for the user to override the handler for a specific lsp to change the semantics for `nil`?

@@ -298,15 +298,25 @@ function M.on_diagnostic(_, result, ctx, config)
   local uri = ctx.params.textDocument.uri

-  if result == nil then

comment_data.body:
I would use "server" instead of "backend", as that's a more common term in LSP lingo. 
```suggestion
        "LSP: client '%s' (id %s) returned nil to textDocument/diagnostic.\nThis is a bug in the LSP server, and should be fixed within '%s'.",
```

+    vim.notify_once(


comment_regular_data.body:
According to the LSP specification https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/lsp/3.17/specification/#textDocument_diagnostic, `result` should never be `nil`, but always be a valid `DocumentDiagnosticReport`.

The `lsp.on_diagnostic` handler implementation (since its first writing #24128) simply ignores the invalid response by checking if `result` is `nil`, just in case the LSP might respond with an invalid response -- rather than aggressively throwing an error. In my view, we should avoid using such workarounds in general, because it may hide or mask bugs, and makes it harder to figure out the root cause of the problem (i.e. invalid responses that violate the LSP protocol). Instead, we can consider adding some one-time (like `vim.notify_once`) warning messages or even assertions to notify users that this is a fault of LSP server implementation, rather than *silently* accepting invalid responses.
Just tested this PR out and can confirm that it **fixes** https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26640. But I agree with @wookayin...seems like this is an issue with Ruby LSP.
@wookayin are you suggesting that we still treat a nil response the same as a response with no items, with the addition of a warning to the user that their LSP backend is misbehaving?
I created https://github.com/Shopify/ruby-lsp/pull/1290 to get this fixed in `ruby-lsp`
Also please check the lintcommit CI output and update the title of PR and commits accordingly.

Im not in favor of adding workarounds for misbehaving servers, unless there is a *very* compelling reason. 

As a project we generally adhere to the position that we implement the specification *as-is*. If a server is non-compliant with the specification, its up to the server to fix that, not for Neovim to work around.

(Moving the comment out of the review thread for better visibility)

> As a workaround, an user may override the handler to change the semantics of and behaviors on nil to "empty diagnostics", in case the LSP server is yet to be fixed and behaves buggy.\

> What would it look like for the user to override the handler for a specific lsp to change the semantics for nil?

An example is as follows (NOTE: this would be a hack, so please use it with a good discernment):

```lua
---@param result lsp.DocumentDiagnosticReport
vim.lsp.handlers["textDocument/diagnostic"] = function(err, result, ctx, config)
  if result == nil -- an invalid response, should never be nil (see #26957)
    -- 1. fail early
    -- error("invalid textDocument/diagnostic response, result is nil")

    -- 2. treat as if an empty response
    result = { kind = "full", items = {} } --[[ @as lsp.FullDocumentDiagnosticReport ]]

    -- 3. or treat as if were an "unchanged" response
    -- result = { kind = "unchanged", resultId = "" } --[[ @as lsp.UnchangedDocumentDiagnosticReport ]]
  end
  return require('vim.lsp.diagnostic').on_diagnostic(err, result, ctx, config)
end
```

`ctx: lsp.HandlerContext` may contain some information about the LSP client.

> Im not in favor of adding workarounds for misbehaving servers, unless there is a _very_ compelling reason.
> 
> As a project we generally adhere to the position that we implement the specification _as-is_. If a server is non-compliant with the specification, its up to the server to fix that, not for Neovim to work around.

I don't disagree in principle, but I'm also conscious of the user experience here.

VSCode handles `nil` responses like [this](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/main/client/src/common/diagnostic.ts#L604):

```typescript
if (result === undefined || result === null || this.isDisposed || token.isCancellationRequested) {
  return { kind: vsdiag.DocumentDiagnosticReportKind.full, items: [] };
}
```

I'm assuming that the majority of LSP backend devs and the majority of devs using the LSP backends are using VSCode. As far as they're concerned, there's no bug here, everything is working fine.

> > Im not in favor of adding workarounds for misbehaving servers, unless there is a _very_ compelling reason.
> > As a project we generally adhere to the position that we implement the specification _as-is_. If a server is non-compliant with the specification, its up to the server to fix that, not for Neovim to work around.
> 
> I don't disagree in principle, but I'm also conscious of the user experience here.
> 
> VSCode handles `nil` responses like [this](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-languageserver-node/blob/main/client/src/common/diagnostic.ts#L604):
> 
> ```ts
> if (result === undefined || result === null || this.isDisposed || token.isCancellationRequested) {
>   return { kind: vsdiag.DocumentDiagnosticReportKind.full, items: [] };
> }
> ```
> 
> I'm assuming that the majority of LSP backend devs and the majority of devs using the LSP backends are using VSCode. As far as they're concerned, there's no bug here, everything is working fine.

Echoing @gpanders and @wookayin, "VSCode does X" isn't a valid reason for us to replicate a hack. We should stick to the protocol as much as possible, and to resolve ambiguities like this we should create an issue in [the specs](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol) asking for clarification on how the client should behave with invalid responses like this.

As others have already stated, we currently have a policy of no workarounds for servers that violate the spec and I don't see a reason to change that. If we'd relax that, we also make it harder for other editors and at some point the specification becomes less and less useful as each editor and server starts doing what they like and build up workarounds for each others quirks.

What I'd be okay with merging is an assert like `assert(response, "Server must return error or response, not nil")`.

> As others have already stated, we currently have a policy of no workarounds for servers that violate the spec and I don't see a reason to change that. If we'd relax that, we also make it harder for other editors and at some point the specification becomes less and less useful as each editor and server starts doing what they like and build up workarounds for each others quirks.

Ok, fair enough. I don't agree that this is the best thing for users in the short term, but understand why you want to keep to the spec.

> What I'd be okay with merging is an assert like `assert(response, "Server must return error or response, not nil")`.

I think the earlier suggestion of `notify_once` is more appropriate here, otherwise the user is spammed with error messages with a traceback every time the backend responds with `nil`.
Not blocking for this PR, but I created https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/1882 to make sure all LSP editors have a consistent behaviour around this.
This has been closed since a request for information has not been answered for 30 days. It can be reopened when the requested information is provided.

title: Handle nil response from backend for diagnostics
